title: I heard a whisper in my ear during an exam
body:
My school is fairly new, and to my knowledge, no one perished during construction, no on-campus suicides (that I know of, at least), and there was never any ghostly rumours that seemed convincing enough to prevent students from walking into that awkwardly positioned toilet of the emptiest hallway. I'm also not one to believe in ghosts.

So an hour and a half into recalling mathematical formulas and aggressive calculator-button-punching, you can imagine my surprise when I felt a breath hot on my left ear.

You see, in an exam condition the tables are a significant distance from one another, so the only thing to enter your 1 meter radius would be the occasional disapproving eyes of the invigilator, or the person next to you getting up for a toilet break. In my situation, I glanced around for a bit and saw nothing out of the ordinary. I panicked, almost considered raising my hand but what would I report? Paranormal activity?

After a full minute of head turning, I decided I wasn't to be accused of cheating, and dismissed it as a passing wind. This is a catholic school, I mean, there is a crucifix pinned next to the exam clock and a painted portrait of St John hanging from one of the pillars. Just outside this hall there is a chapel where morning mass is held every Friday. We clasp our hands in prayer as a cohort before each test. The guy to my right is an altar boy. Everything was fine, until I heard it again.

This time the breath was a whisper-toned word, but even then I could make out that it belonged to a female, shrill enough to serve as a soprano in the choir. I jumped, of course, my heart was pulsing from my throat. This time it was definitely not a passing wind.

Being the catholic school girl I was, my hand shot up. Get the invigilator to know about this, was my first thought. But receiving no attention, my second thought was, what did it say?

It said a single one-syllable word, 'don't'.

Now to think about it, it probably said the same thing the first time. It's easy to mistake the 'o' vowel for a breath or a yawn. But here it was clear as day, even as a whisper it enunciated the consonants well enough to produce what seemed like a warning, 'don't'.

Or maybe it could have been just a breath, or really just a passing wind, I don't know. I was already afraid of the ticking minute-hand against my unprepared standard of mathematical knowledge, and now this. What is this? Don't? What?

I had to be out of my mind, or something, because I started to think of everything the voice was trying to warn me about. Don't...apply this formula? Don't...move on to the next question yet?

And just like that I went back to my exam. I was a rational human being who had forgotten what rational numbers were despite learning about them in third grade. I was a rational human being who didn't believe in ghosts.

When there was but one question left empty, I received another surprise.

I saw your name.

Carved into the last sheet of paper with black printed ink, I saw your name.

I always liked your name! It had an oriental ring to it when said in full and you went by acronyms because I guess it sounded cool to you. I always liked that it was unique, your acronyms spelt out a function notation.

And now here it sat, disguised as a solvable equation in the midst of all my panic, serving as some form of consolation. I loved you, it made me happy to see your name like that!

And when the papers were passed up and my small encounter with the passing wind fled my mind, there you were, I could see you past a sea of heads, could swim through all of them to get to you and tell you how I managed to solve the equation with your name in it but then I remembered.

You never loved me back, not even the smallest fraction of the devotion I had towards you. You would never look at me the same way I was afraid to rest my gaze on your coffee coloured corneas, you would never want me the same way I fell in love with your every charcoal eyelash bat. I was only good enough to listen to your voice like a sweet silicone daydream from distances away. But you had the softest smile. You were too beautiful to love me back.

So I watched you walk away, the glow from the sticky summer light clinging onto your shoulders like a lover. Even in leaving you looked like magic.

And then I was back in the toilet of the emptiest hallway, the woman standing behind me in the mirror flashed a sad smile.

'Don't.'
author: abortedwhore
